journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part J: Journal of Engineering Tribology

title-group.article-title: Effect of MoS2 on the tribological properties of in situ Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Xi'an, People's Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: Yaping Bai and Jiandong Xing, State Key Laboratory for Mechanical Behavior of Materials, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Xi'an Jiaotong University, 28 Xianning West Road, Xi'an, Shaanxi Province 710049, People's Republic of China. Email: jingpingxue2004@163.com; jdxing@mail.xjtu.edu.cn

abstract.p: Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites containing 0, 5 and 8 wt% MoS2 were subjected to mechanical alloying-inducing self-propagating high temperature synthesis with subsequent hot-pressing sintering. Microstructures of the composites were studied by X-ray diffraction, scanning electron microscopy and energy dispersive spectrum analysis. Then the relative density, room temperature hardness and dry sliding wear behavior of the sintered composites at 25 °C, 500 °C and 800 °C were tested and analyzed. The results showed that composites with different amounts of added MoS2 had good microstructure with high relative density and high hardness. The MoS2 decomposes during sintering with the formation of Fe3Mo3C and Cr2S3. Cr2S3 formed from the decomposition process may form a lubricating film that can decrease the friction coefficient. At 800 °C, Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr with 8 wt% added MoS2 exhibited a friction coefficient that was nearly 50% lower than that for the sample with no MoS2 addition. Addition of 8 wt% MoS2 transformed the wear mechanism from adhesive wear to microploughing.

kwd-group.kwd: In situ Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Intermetallic matrix composites reinforced with carbides, nitrides, borides or oxides have received extensive attention in recent years.1–3 The composites are expected to combine the high temperature and wear resistance properties of ceramic with the engineering properties of intermetallics.1–4 The Fe–Al alloys possess advantageous properties such as high speciﬁc strength (strength/density ratio), excellent fatigue and creep strength, and good corrosion resistance at elevated temperatures under the environments of oxidation and sulfidation.5,6 Thus, they are useful in friction and wear industries.7 In some early reports, Al2O3-reinforced Fe3Al intermetallic composites manufactured by mechanical alloying (MA) with subsequent hot processing and dry sliding wear behavior were also reported.8 Under working conditions with high wear, materials should have not only excellent tribological properties but also good mechanical properties to ensure good safety operation. To date, many studies9,10 have revealed that Cr element has a positive effect on plasticity and toughness of iron aluminides, without obvious hardness and strength decrease.

In addition, introduction of the direct particles into the matrix results in poor compatibility of the matrix and reinforcements and restricted distribution and wettability of reinforcements in the matrix, etc. So, in comparison, the in situ method is more favorable.

Molybdenum disulﬁde (MoS2), an important solid lubricant with excellent friction and wear properties under inert or vacuum environments, has been widely studied because of its unique lamellar crystal structure with an inherently low shear strength and hence low friction.11 Many studies have shown that MoS2 as the lubricating phase could have a positive effect on the tribological properties of materials.12,13

In this research, different amounts of MoS2 were added to the in situ Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr matrix, which was prepared by mechanical alloying-inducing self-propagating high temperature synthesis with subsequent hot-pressing sintering (MA-HP), and dry sliding wear properties at 25 °C, 500 °C and 800 °C were investigated, respectively.

sec.title: Experimental procedures
sec.p:
Iron powder (200 mesh, 99.00 wt% purity), aluminum powder (200 mesh, 99.00 wt% purity), chromium powder (200 mesh, 99.95 wt% purity) and ferric oxide (200 mesh, 99.00 wt% purity) were mixed in a composition of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% elemental Cr element. Under argon atmosphere, the mixed powders and 10 mm-sized stainless steel balls with a ball-to-powder weight ratio of 10:1 were packed in a stainless steel vessel. A planetary ball miller was used at 250 rpm for 5 h. Then the as-milled powders with 0.5 ml methanol added (about 0.8 wt% of the total powder amount) were milled for 50 h.14 After the milling time (50 h), different amounts of MoS2 were added into the vessel and mixed for another 5 h. Table 1 shows the raw materials for the three samples. For simplicity of discussion, the compositions with 0 wt% MoS2, 5 wt% MoS2 and 8 wt% MoS2 were denoted as FM0, FM5 and FM8, respectively. Table 1.
The raw materials for the three materials of the test.
Samples Fe powder (g) Al powder (g) Fe2O3 powder (g) Cr powder (g) MoS2 powder (g)
FM0 27.06 12.48 18.03 2.43 0
FM5 25.71 11.85 17.13 2.31 3.0
FM8 24.89 11.48 16.59 2.24 4.8
MoS2: molybdenum disulﬁde.

A total of 30 g of milled powders were packed in a graphite die (inner size Ø24 × 80 mm, outer size Ø60 × 80 mm) to be cold compacted at a pressure of 10 MPa and then the specimen was sintered in a vacuum hot pressing furnace (ZT-45-20, Shanghai Chen hua Electric Furnace Corp Ltd, China) at 30 MPa (10−2 Pa). The sintering was conducted at 1300 °C for 30 min, followed by furnace cooling. The dimensions of the samples obtained after sintering were about Ø24 × 10 mm.

Densities were measured using Archimedes’ method. Phase analyses were measured by X-ray diffraction (XRD). The microstructure and phase compositions were characterized using scanning electron microscope (SEM) equipped with energy dispersive spectrum (EDS) analysis.

The bulk hardnesses of FM0, FM5, FM8 and the counterpart Inconel 718 were measured on an HRS-150 Digital Rockwell Hardness Machine with applied load of 1470 N and the bulk hardness (HRC) values of the specimens were determined by the mean of five measurements.

The friction and wear tests at 25 °C, 500 °C and 800 °C were carried out by a pin-on-disk wear tester. The pin specimen was ﬁxed and the disk specimen rotated at different speeds. The pin specimens, size was 5.0 × 5.0 × 10.0 mm and one tip was prepared to be hemispherical, with a diameter 5.0 mm, were made of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites; the disk specimens, 44 mm in diameter and 6 mm in thickness, were made of Inconel 718. The heat treatment process for Inconel 718 was solution treatment at 980 °C for 1 h, air cooling, then aging treatment at 720 °C for 8 h, cooling to 620 °C for 8 h, and then aging treatment. After the heat treatment, the bulk hardness of Inconel 718 was about 42.0 HRC. The surface roughness of pin specimens and disc specimens were Ra = 0.30 and 0.15 µm, respectively.

sec.title: Microstructure and hardness of the as-consolidated FM0, FM5 and FM8 samples
sec.p: In previous studies, the XRD patterns and microstructure of the as-milled powders (FM0) have been investigated.15

In order to obtain Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3 composites (20 wt% Al2O3 is calculated), elemental Fe was added to the starting materials as shown below (reaction (1)) (1)3Fe2O3+12.29Al+12.87Fe+X Cr =18.87Fe+6.29Al+3Al2O3+X Cr

The value of X is 1.24 when Cr content is 4 wt%. Tad >1300 K is necessary for the reaction initiated by MA, Tad can be calculated from the following formula (formula (2))16–18 (2)ΔH=∫T0TmsCpdT+∫TmTad1CpdT+ΔHm where ΔH is the enthalpy of the reaction, lCp is the molar heat capacity of the liquid product, sCp is the molar heat capacity of the solid product, Tad is the adiabatic temperature of the reaction, T0 is the initial temperature (298.15 K), Tm is the melting point of the product and ΔHm is the melting enthalpy of the solid phase. Tad is 1882 K and the value is higher than 1300 K, so the reaction can proceed during the MA process.

Bai et al. [15] proved that MA-inducing self-propagating high temperature synthesis can take place. Therefore, in this article, on the basis of the early work, only the bulk FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites after preparation HP were discussed.

The relative densities of sintered composites were measured using Archimedes' method. The results show that the densities of all the composites are more than 99%. Subsequently, the bulk hardnesses of FM0, FM5, FM8 and the counterpart Inconel 718 were measured and the results indicated that the hardnesses of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites were 42.5 HRC, 35.1 HRC and 37.8 HRC, respectively. The hardness of FM5 and FM8 is lower than that of FM0 but the composite with 8 wt% MoS2 has higher hardness value than that with 5 wt% MoS2. It can be concluded that Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites with different amounts of MoS2 added have good sintering quality. The role of addition of MoS2 can be analyzed from two aspects. On the one hand, MoS2 addition can induce decrease in hardness and on the other hand, the melting MoS2 would enhance the densities of composites.

Microstructures of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites with different amounts of MoS2 added consolidated by HP are shown in Figure 1. It can be observed that FM0 and FM5 have two types of phases, black and gray, but there are three types of phases on the FM8 composite, the black, white and gray phases. The black and white phases are well dispersed in the composites with grain size less than 10 µm. Figure 1(c) shows the composition of the white phases of FM8 composites. The white zone contains 54.01 wt% Mo element, 32.60 wt% Fe element, 6.93 wt% Cr element, 1.93 wt% Al element and 4.53 wt% C element. So it can be deduced that the white zone contains Mo compounds. But the white zone does not occur in the FM5 sample. All these results may be attributed to the lower content of Mo in the FM5 sample than that in the FM8 sample and the S element volatilization; therefore, S and Mo elements cannot be detected in the FM5 sample using EDS. Figure 1.
Microstructure and XRD analysis of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites with different added MoS2 amounts.: (a) FM0 sample, (b) FM5 sample and (c) FM8 sample.
XRD: X-ray diffraction; MoS2: molybdenum disulﬁde.

The XRD analyses of different composites are also shown in Figure 1. It can be seen that superlattice reflection peaks such as (111), (200) or (222) are not found in the three specimens consolidated by HP19 and it indicates that disordered Fe(Al) solid solution, which is formed after the MA process,15 is retained in specimens prepared by HP. Carbon is also detected by XRD because of methanol addition during the MA process and graphite die used in HP.

In the XRD analysis of FM5 sample, the eutectic compounds CrxSy or Fe3Mo3C did not appear. It may be due to the lower amount of MoS2 in the FM5 sample. For the XRD analysis of FM8 sample, besides disordered Fe(Al) solid solution and α-Al2O3, new phases such as Fe3Mo3C and Cr2S3 also exist in the bulk material. There is no MoS2 phase detected in the composites due to the decomposition of MoS2 that occurred during HP. Thus, the S element can be combined with Cr element to form Fe–Al–Cr solid solution and eutectic compounds of CrxSy (x/y = (2/3)∼1). Because amount of Cr is about 4 wt%, only Cr2S3 is formed after the sintering process. The residual Mo with Fe and C formed the Fe3Mo3C compounds. All the analysis of XRD are consistent with the EDS results.

sec.title: Tribological properties of the composites
sec.p:
Figure 2 illustrates the heating device and pin-on-disc dry sliding wear tester. Pre- and post-testing, the specimens were ultrasonically cleaned in an acetone bath for 15 min and then the mass of each specimen was measured using an electronic balance, with an accuracy of 0.01 mg. The mass of every specimen was determined by calculating the mean of at least six measurements, respectively. The friction force was measured with a load cell and converted into the friction coefficient. The wear mass loss (Δm) was the difference in mass value before and after wear testing (after sliding the complete distance) and the value is the mean of three measurements. The wear rate (w) was calculated according to the following expression (3)w=Δmρ·l·N where ρ is the density of the test material, l is the sliding distance and N is the load. Every test result was the average of the wear volume loss for three specimens. The abrasive dust was collected at the end of each test. Figure 2.
Schematic illustration and heating device of pin-on-disc dry sliding wear tester: (a) the dry sliding wear tester device and (b) the heating device.

For validating the effect of MoS2 on the wear performance of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites at 25 °C, 500 °C and 800 °C, FM5 and FM8 are chosen as the research materials and FM0 as the contrast material for dry sliding wear test at different temperatures. Wang et al.20 and Bai et al.21 have studied the dry sliding wear behavior of Fe3Al alloys prepared by plasma-activated sintering against GCr15 bearing steels. From their study, it can be seen that wear rate of Fe3Al alloys increases (with a small friction coefficient decrease) as applied load increases and reaches a peak at 30 N. As the sliding speed increased, the wear rate decreased but the friction coefficient did not change much. The analysis indicates that Fe3Al alloys have the most rigorous wear under 30 N applied load and 0.26 m/s sliding speed at room temperature. Therefore, the wear test parameters are 30 N applied load and 0.26 m/s sliding speed at 25 °C, 500 °C and 800 °C for 1923 s, respectively. Each test is repeated three times. The detailed parameters of dry sliding friction and wear test are shown in Table 2. Table 2.
Parameters of dry sliding friction and wear test.
Load (N) Sliding speed (m·s−1) Sliding distance (m) Sliding radius (mm) Sliding time (s) Spindle speed (r·min−1) Testing temperature(°C)
30 0.26 500 12.5 1923 200 25, 500, 800

Figure 3 shows the friction coefficients of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites after wear tests at different temperatures. It can be seen that MoS2 can have a positive effect on the tribological properties of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3 composites during the dry sliding wear at room and high temperatures. At 500 °C, both FM5 and FM8 samples were worn off quickly. So a 500 °C wear test was conducted. Furthermore, the variation in the friction coefficient of FM0, FM5 and FM8 samples, as shown in Figure 4, also indicated the serious wear of FM5 and FM8 composites. Figure 3.
Friction coefficients FM0, FM5 and FM8 samples after different temperature wear tests.
Figure 4.
Friction coefficient variation of FM0, FM5 and FM8 samples with sliding time at 500 °C.

Figure 5 shows the wear rates of FM0, FM5, FM8 and the corresponding counterpart Inconel 718 disks after wear tests at different temperatures. Figure 5(a) indicates that the wear rates of FM5 and FM8 specimens are higher than that of FM0 at room temperature. But at 800 °C, the wear rates of the three pins are approximately of the same magnitude and FM8 sample has the lowest wear rate. It can be concluded that the addition of MoS2 lubricant can have a positive effect on the tribological properties of composites during the high temperature wear test at 800 °C. Figure 5.
Wear rates of FM0, FM5, FM8 and the corresponding counterpart Inconel 718 after different temperature wear tests: (a) wear rates of FM0, FM5, FM8 samples and (b) wear rates of the corresponding counterpart Inconel 718.

Figure 5(b) shows the wear rates of Inconel 718 at different temperatures. When the temperature increased to 800 °C, the wear rates changed from negative to positive. Therefore, it can be deduced that the wear rate of pins is the algebraic sum of the wear weight loss of FM0, FM5 and FM8 pins and the transfer weight gain of the corresponding Inconel 718 disks. On the worn surface of the disk, it can be deduced that there is a significant amount of adhesive material from the corresponding pins. On the other hand, because the disks have large wear scars, the loose debris can deposit easily under the rolling force during wear process. Although the pin and disk were ultrasonically cleaned in acetone bath for 15 min after wear test, it did not eliminate the loose debris coating on the worn surface.

sec.title: Wear mechanism at room temperature
sec.p:
The worn surface morphologies of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites after wear test at room temperature are shown in Figure 6. It can be seen that large amount of big and uneven patches of material exist on the worn surface of FM0 composite and no obvious plastic deformation exists. From the EDS results shown in Table 3, it can be concluded that the white patches mainly consisted of Ni elements and its oxides, which were transferred from the corresponding counterpart Inconel 718 disk. The worn morphology and EDS analysis prove that the main wear mechanism of FM0 is adhesive wear. The phenomenon of microploughing is obviously found on both the FM5 and FM8 worn surfaces (see Figure 6(b) and (c)) and the microploughing is more serious on the worn surface of FM8 composite than that on the worn surface of FM5 composite. Figure 6.
Worn surface morphology of FM0, FM5 and FM8 after wear test at room temperature: (a) FM0 sample, (b) FM5 sample and (c) FM8 sample.
Table 3.
EDS results (at.%) of the points marked in Figure 6(c), Figures 8(a) and (c).
Figures Spectra C O Al S Ti Cr Fe Ni Nb Mo
Figure 6(c) Point 1 8.42 6.73 2.04 0.00 1.63 17.07 16.33 45.34 2.44 0.00
Point 2 0.00 12.80 21.60 2.69 0.00 5.36 48.73 6.83 0.00 1.98
Point 3 0.00 9.36 19.80 3.56 0.00 3.01 64.24 0.00 0.00 0.00
Figure 8(a) Point 1 4.99 61.22 12.97 0.00 0.00 0.53 19.82 0.46 0.00 0.00
Point 2 0.00 49.26 8.89 0.00 0.00 0.00 41.77 0.00 0.00 0.00
Figure 8(c) Point 1 8.74 57.49 8.10 0.18 0.00 2.32 18.79 3.62 0.00 0.77
Point 2 0.00 44.63 21.2 2.13 0.00 2.24 29.18 0.00 0.00 0.62
EDS: energy dispersive spectrum.

Figure 6(b) and (c) also show there are some patches on the worn surface of FM5 and FM8 pins. Combined with the EDS analysis of the worn surfaces of FM8 composite (Table 3), the patches consist of Cr, Fe, Al, Ni, O and Mo elements and the O amount is higher than that at point 3. From the atomic percent of each element, it can be deduced that the patches are the compositions of pin materials, disk materials and some oxides due to the increasing temperature during the friction process.22–24 The melting point of the eutectic compounds CrxSy is in the range of 600–900 °C, which allows plastic deformation of CrxSy to take place easily at elevated temperatures.25,26 Therefore, in this research, Cr2S3 (one kind of CrxSy eutectic compound) can soften or melt during friction heating to form a lubricating film, which can improve the tribological properties. The lubricating effect of oxides on the worn surface of composites contributes to the further reduction of the friction coefficient.

The hardness of Inconel 718 (42.0 HRC) is higher than that of FM5 composite (35.1 HRC) and FM8 composite (37.8 HRC) at room temperature. Thus, there is some microploughing on the worn surface of the FM5 and FM8 samples, which can be attributed to the cutting effect of the disk during the dry sliding wear process. With the addition of MoS2 lubricant, the plastic performances of composites are improved with the formation of Cr2S3 during wear process, so that the microploughing is more serious on the worn surface of FM8 composite. The above analysis indicated that composites with 8 wt% MoS2 addition have improved wear performance at room temperature. The above discussion shows that the wear mechanism of FM0 composites is mainly adhesive wear while the wear mechanism of FM5 and FM8 composites are dominated by microploughing and slight oxidative wear at room temperature. Therefore, the wear performance of the composites can be improved by adding a certain amount of MoS2 in Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr matrix.

sec.title: Wear mechanism at 500 °C
sec.p: Pauschitz et al.27 has demonstrated that wear mechanisms can also be determined by careful evaluation of the surface roughness of the worn surfaces, without destroying, using 3D surface topography measurement equipment. For further exploration of the wear mechanisms, 3D laser scanning images and the surface roughness were acquired using a VK-9710K color 3D laser microscope.

Figure 7 shows the worn surface morphologies and 3D laser scanning images of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites at 500 °C, respectively. The study of Wang et al.28 showed that the hardness of Inconel 718 is constant with increasing temperature but the hardness of FM0, FM5 and FM8 would decreases as the temperature increases to 500 °C; therefore, the ploughing in the worn surface is greater than that at room temperature and both the FM5 and FM8 samples are worn down quickly. For example, Figure 7(c) shows that the FM8 sample has rather high surface roughness (6.014 µm), similar to the variation of wear rates and the friction coefficient of composites with or without MoS2 addition at 500 °C. The wear mechanism of the composites with or without MoS2 addition is also completely different. The FM0 sample shows a lot of adhesive material on the worn surface, such as the white parts. But the worn surfaces of FM5 and FM8 composite are all covered by deep grooves. Therefore, MoS2 addition did not improve the wear properties significantly but the wear mechanism has been changed from adhesive wear to ploughing and slight oxidation wear. Figure 7.
Worn surface morphology of worn surface of FM0, FM5 and FM8 after wear test at 500 °C: (a) FM0 sample, (b) FM5 sample and (c) FM8 sample.

sec.title: Wear mechanism at 800 °C
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the worn surface morphologies and 3D laser scanning images of FM0, FM5 and FM8 composites at 800 °C. The study of Wang et al.28 shows that the hardness of Inconel 718 is constant when the temperature was lower than 760 °C but it decreases slightly when the temperature increases to 800 °C. However, the hardnesses of FM0 and FM8 decrease significantly when the temperature increases to 800 °C. This is because the ploughing of the worn surface is greater than that at room temperature. Figure 8(c) shows that the worn surface of FM8 composite is covered by an integrated and smooth layer, with the surface roughness value decreasing to 0.582 µm, which is much lower than that of the FM0 sample. The variation in the surface roughness also compares well with the wear rates of those two composites. Thus, it can be concluded that the addition of MoS2 lubricant can have a positive effect on the wear performance of composites. Figure 8.
Worn surface morphology of worn surface of FM0, FM5 and FM8 after wear test at 800 °C: (a) FM0 sample, (b) FM5 sample and (c) FM8 sample.

The composition of the worn surface and abrasive debris of FM8 composite is investigated by EDS and XRD analysis, as shown in Table 3 and Figure 9. The EDS results show that the composition of the lubricating layer on the worn surface of FM8 composite mainly comprises O, Fe, Al and Ni elements (Table 3). Furthermore, the XRD analysis results of the abrasive debris of FM8 composite after wear test at 800 °C show that the abrasive debris primarily consisted of Fe2O3 and Al2O3 (Figure 9). In previous studies, Wang et al.29 have shown that NiO could be formed when the temperature is above 500 °C and it is a high temperature solid lubricant that has excellent plasticity and adhesion. However, in this study, NiO was not detected on the abrasive debris; maybe its contents were lower than those that could be detected by XRD analysis. Combined with the XRD analysis and EDS results of FM8 composite after wear test at 800 °C (Figure 9), it was found that the lubricating layer on the worn surface of FM8 composite is a mixture of the pin (Fe2O3 or Al2O3) and disk (NiO) materials, which could prevent the direct contact of the pin and disk. The formation of lubricating layer on the worn surface of FM8 composite can improve the tribological properties. Figure 9.
XRD analysis of abrasive debris of FM8 after wear test at 800 °C.
XRD: X-ray diffraction.

For further analysis of the friction and wear mechanism of the composites, Figure 10 shows the 3D laser scanning images of the worn surfaces of Inconel 718 against FM0 and FM8 after wear tests at 25 °C and 800 °C, respectively. The results show that the roughness of the Inconel 718 disk mating with FM0 (3.263 µm) at room temperature and with FM0 (3.747 µm) at 800 °C is much higher than that of Inconel 718 mating with FM8 (0.966 µm) at room temperature and with FM8 (0.368 µm) at 800 °C. Figure 10(c) also shows a lot of adhesion material from the corresponding pins. The variation of roughness can be attributed to the addition of MoS2 lubricant because Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr with added MoS2 amount can form a good lubricating layer on the worn surface during the wear test, which can decrease the friction coefficient and furthermore, decrease the adhesion trend. All the results of the disks are consistent with the surface analysis of the corresponding worn pin, friction coefficients and the wear rates. Above all, 8 wt% MoS2 can have a positive effect on the wear performance of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites, especially at 800 °C. Figure 10.
3D laser scanning images of the Inconel 718 worn surfaces surface against FM0 and FM8 after 25 °C and 800 °C, respectively: (a) Inconel 718 against FM0 after 25 °C wear test, (b) Inconel 718 against FM8 after 25 °C wear test, (c) Inconel 718 against FM0 after 800 °C wear test and (d) Inconel 718 against FM8 after 800 °C wear test.

list-item.p: Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites with 5 wt% and 8 wt% MoS2 addition were prepared by MA with subsequent HP. The MoS2 decomposes during sintering process. Cr2S3 formed from the decomposition process can form a lubricating film that can decrease the friction coefficient.

The friction coefficients of Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composite with added 8 wt% MoS2 (FM8) amount decrease significantly when the temperature increases to 800 °C. The wear mechanism of FM8 composite is dominated by microploughing at room temperature and the main wear mechanism is microploughing and oxidation wear at 800 °C.
Adding 8 wt% MoS2 to Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites can have a positive effect on the dry sliding wear resistance performance at high temperatures, i.e. at 800 °C.
The adding of MoS2 lubricant to Fe3Al-20 wt% Al2O3-4 wt% Cr composites causes the wear mechanism to change from adhesive wear to microploughing.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was supported by the National Nature Science Foundation of China (grant no. 50871084).
